segments.text: This is an interview with Mr. Bob Kuhn by Syed Haider on April 25, 1989, concerning the Vietnam War.
In the interest of accumulating knowledge about the war, I'm going to donate this tape to the Texas A&M Oral History Collection in the University Archives.
Is that all right with you?
Yes.
Mr. Kuhn, can you tell us how and why you joined the military?
Can you include a brief sketch of military career before Vietnam?
Oh, I joined the Army and, uh,
December 6, 1960, I was drafted.
I volunteered my draft.
I was looking to just take two years and get back out.
But after I had served about a year, I decided to make the military my career.
Can you tell us something about where you went to college?
I've only got a few credits in college and stuff.
When I was in the military, I went to school and stuff like this because I needed this to get my promotion to my next higher grade.
So I went to NCO Academy, different type of school, a few credit hours here and there, but no college.
When did you first go to Vietnam?
The first time I arrived in Vietnam was in May of 65, the 173rd.
in Okinawa, was ordered to move from Okinawa to Vietnam as an action force.
But after a few months there, Johnson decided to make the 173rd a permanent change of station.
And we were stationed in Vietnam.
But I had orders to come back home in August.
So I came back in August of 65, served about a year in 82nd Airborne, and turned around and went right back to Okinawa in 67.
I arrived back in Vietnam in February of 67 as a special forces advisory team, what they called a Bravo team.
building Spatial Forces A camps for the Spatial Forces from north to south.
That was from the north end of Vietnam to the south end of Vietnam.
When I arrived in Vietnam, I started at the north end building Spatial Forces camp and airstrips and things like this for the Spatial Forces.
Then I moved from there to Canto to build a floating camp that we built.
And then we moved from there to...
another camp, and we built a wall for during the floods in the Mekong that the camp would not be flooded.
Then I left Vietnam then for, I served about eight months.
I came back in August again, and I left Okinawa in 69 and served about another year back in the States with the 82nd because I've been a paratrooper.
I turned around and went right back to Vietnam.
This time it was an actual tour in Vietnam because the other times that I was there was considered as a TDY tour, and my time there did not count.
So this time that I was going back in 60, in 71, was an actual Vietnam assignment from the government branch.
Okay, then I served a year.
That was my years, what we had to serve in a combat zone.
When you went to Vietnam the second time, did you notice a change in the attitude of the American forces there from their attitude when you first were there?
I think it was about the same.
It was a little bit different than most of the people that was there.
I guess the people, once that they got accepted, the military especially, they just accepted it as a tour.
So they accepted their job in being in the military as a duty.
There was maybe some that wasn't, but most of the time I didn't meet people that objected for being there.
And some in cases, we had people stay three and four years as volunteers to stay there.
So in other words, some people liked it and some people didn't.
What do you believe was the reason for American involvement in Vietnam?
The government, I think, asked after France
had lost to them.
And we also had advisory there starting in 65, or long before the 173rd was moved there, that we had advisories and MACV units there advising the Vietnamese troops and government about the war.
And then 65 was when Johnson moved, actually put American forces in Vietnam.
Can you reflect on some of the problems you encountered while you were in Vietnam?
For example, did you see people who had problems with abuse of drugs or alcohol?
Yes, there was a lot of that going on.
They had their little groups.
Just like in your ethnic groups, even in Nam, they...
You had your ethnic groups, your Puerto Ricans stuck together, your blacks stuck together, your potheads or your people that use drugs.
Even in those groups, they mostly stuck together and done everything as their own ethnic groups.
Because the type of job I had at the time then was not a combat MOS.
It was a maintenance MOS.
And so I stayed around in camp.
So in other words, the people, mostly for what I seen in Nam at that time,
was, except for in 67 when I was more in a combat type field, that the troops were mostly ethnic oriented.
In other words, when the blacks would raise their hands, the Puerto Ricans had their own little things to do off of what the blacks had.
They'd do this.
And they'd do different things that, you know.

There was a few white guys that could pick it up, but if they associated them within, because they were smoking pot or they were taking drugs, mostly that I know of, the big thing that a lot of the troops were doing was mostly smoking the pot.
You could find a lot of these bags and things of pot around the buildings.
Anything after payday, a lot of times they'd go buy it.
And they'd smoke it.
And that's how they stuck together.
Like I said, most of them was just ethnic groups.
So you did not associate yourself with other ethnic groups?
I associated with them, but I was not part of them.
In other words, my job as an NCO or a sergeant within the Army, I associated with them, but I was not part of their group because I could not be part of their group and be an NCO.
Unless I wanted to go ahead and smoke the pot and be like them, then I could do it.
Then you could be one of the fellas.

For all the time that I was in Vietnam and stuff like this, I had no urge to take drugs or smoke the pot because I looked at it as a Christian and stuff like this, that it was not good for your body and things like this to be doing this.
Plus, I wanted to come back from Vietnam a full person because you don't know what some of this stuff would do to your body.
How do you think were the blacks treated in Vietnam?
I think the blacks are treated about like everybody else.

I mean, it was probably, as I said before, that it was probably another victory for them because of their involvement in Vietnam and losing their lives just like the Americans were in other wars and stuff like this.
They were segregated into their own little groups were in Vietnam.
or this type of combat more, they were associated with more of the Americans.
So they approved themselves.
In other words, some of them got medals of honors and was awarded medal of honors.
They may not be here to have the medal, their parents have it, but they sacrificed their lives to save other American lives, the blacks.
So the blacks and whites associated freely in Vietnam?
Right.
There was a few problems maybe, but like I said, they stuck to their selves.
even though they knew that they had to still be together.

Like I think in any type of combat situation, you can have your different ethnic groups, but in a situation when you go to the field as a military involvement action, everybody works together because everybody has to look out for surviving.
So they work together.
While the American soldiers were fighting in the jungles of Southeast Asia, do you think it was right for many other Americans to protest against the war?
Well, I guess that would have to go back to the freedom of speech.
I mean, I didn't think too much of people being back here while I was over there to me as being a military
Fighting for our country and these people back here protesting the war, like I said, their opinions and my opinions are different, so everybody has their views of the war.
So if that's what they wanted to do, I guess, you know.
Our government is often referred to as the, and I quote, government of the people, by the people, and for the people.
In 1971, a Harris poll showed that 71% of those questioned thought we had made a mistake by sending troops to Vietnam in the first place.
58% regarded the war as immoral, and a majority favored pulling all our troops out of Vietnam
by the end of 1971, even if that meant a communist takeover of the country.
The Nixon administration continued the bombing and killing even after this.
Do you believe it was right for a democratic government to go against the will of the majority when the dissent was so obvious?
The political people back here
thought we shouldn't be in Vietnam.
And after a while, I guess, the government, Nixon, as you said, started pulling the troops out, or had started planning on pulling out the troops in Nam.
And so he had so much political pressure put against him because we were not going anywhere in Vietnam.

So as you stated within your paper, even though we were going to pull out, that we were not going to support the people no longer, and it would turn into a communist country, which is what really happened after we moved out.
Because after we moved out in 73, the North Vietnamese, the Viet Cong, actually just because of us leaving, the people no longer, the fighting people tried for what I think about another,
Not too long after we pulled out, they didn't fight too long, and the country was given up, and the whole country was taken over.
President Eisenhower in 1965 had believed that if Vietnam went to the communists, then the rest of the Asia would fall, and I quote, like a row of dominoes.
almost 15 years after the Vietnam went to the Communists, we did not see many Asian countries falling to the Communists.
Do you believe that President Eisenhower was wrong by exaggerating the extent and the importance of Vietnam?
I think what Eisenhower said could have possibly happened.
It all depends on how
after North Vietnam and Red China, wanted to push things after they took over North Vietnam and supported the North Vietnamese.
If they felt more strongly of taking other countries like they are right now, I think we still have problems in Cambodia and different places like this that they're trying to...
take over.
So part of this is still might be coming true.
It's not a big thing going, even though just North Vietnam was the only one that was taken over and it became communism.
Do you feel that Americans understood the culture of South Vietnam and the Americans had the ability to speak for the South Vietnamese people?
Were we really trying to do what...
I think we were trying to do what we were required to do with the country, but it became such a political thing after a while, after so many years of us being in NAM.
And we were, as I always looked at too, for the United States being as big as we were, that we could not go and do certain things.
There was a lot of things...
we couldn't do in Vietnam because of orders like we couldn't put ammunition or something like this in the weapons and you're in a combat zone in certain areas.
These were pretty cool things.

These people all looked alike over there so if you're going to protect yourself, why should I have a weapon on me but I cannot put ammunition in it and be ready for any type of thing that might happen because
All their people looked alike to me over there.
Even the person that could, a lot of times we had the same problem, that we had the people from Vietnam were double agents.
They were working both sides of the fence, as you can call.
Some of them would, since they, you know, they would work for us and they also worked for the Viet Cong, they were double agents.
And they were also troops that were double agents.

would work and we had sent out a lot of people a lot of times and our people got shot in the back because of the other people so you could never tell it uh so did you all have a hard time distinguishing the enemy right you would have a hard time distinguishing the enemy because they all just like when you even if he was talking about the japanese now they would be a little different because we did not support
the Japanese like we did the Vietnamese, that we were fighting them so we knew who we were fighting.
It would be kind of difficult also during World War II when you were fighting Germans.
German people look like us.
If they put clothes on or put uniforms on like us and could talk our language, we
could accept them as the Americans and they could go right in and be enemy people.
Where in Viet Cong or Vietnamese, we were over there working with them alongside them.
We did not know if we were working alongside a Viet Cong or a good person.
So it was a hard situation.
I think especially in some of the jobs that we had,
You couldn't trust the people.
I had good friends over there.
I made good friends with a lot of people over there.
But still, I think there were still cases where people couldn't trust them because of knowing other people had turned or found out they were double agents.
Mr. Coon, what do you believe was the cause of America's loss in Vietnam?
I think we really didn't lose in Vietnam.
Yeah, we lost a lot of lives and things, but we were there for the government, our government, working along with the Vietnamese government.

And after it became such a political type thing that we were not going anywhere, and it was a big expense for us being there, that the government just decided to pull our troops and American forces back out of Vietnam.
Yes, we pulled out, and a lot of our troops looked at it as a war we never won.
So in other words, that could be what they're saying, what you just said, was that a loss, which it would be a loss.
It was something we never completed.
Why do you think that happened?
Why do you think the government pulled out the troops?
The American peoples back here just thought that we shouldn't be there after a period of time.
It was just a big, big thing.
And most of it was political.
I was just serving in the military, so really I did not get involved with looking why the government sent me there.
I did not ask questions of why the government sent me there, because I was in the US military in an army.
That was my job if they sent me there.
The times they sent me there are different times.
They sent me there, it was my job, so I went.
But when they asked me to come back, I came back.
I mean, I felt bad that we'd come back.
Well, really, I wasn't there at the time they started pulling them out.
But I looked at it as being at Fort Bragg, North Carolina, and was hearing on the radio news that Nixon had started pulling troops out of Nam.
I think most of it was just a big political thing.
And re-election and things like this were coming up, just like when Eisenhower was getting re-elected or was elected, he was pulling troops out of Korea and things like this.
And so that helped him get, because people favored that, so they went ahead and elected him.
But Nixon had promised in 1968 that he's going to pull out the troops very soon.
But after that, he continued the bombing of North Vietnam, and America is said to have dropped more bombs on North Vietnam than bombs dropped in the entire World War II on Germany.
So do you think that Nixon kept his promise of withdrawing from Vietnam as soon as he had said he would?
Like he said, he was talking about pulling them out, but I think he still looked at it that we had an obligation to the country, the Vietnamese, the country he was supporting.
And then he did start really pulling them out until about five years later, I think.
He pulled them out in 1973, was actually when we started pulling the troops out of Vietnam.
that I think, like you say, it was a political war, and so he was just waiting the right time to pull them out.

I mean, as they always said, like you said, that they dropped more bombs there, but a lot of those bombs, when they dropped, did not hit solid ground, and the reason they don't explode was because they go into the ground, and they're sitting over there, and a lot of the bombs may not even have exploded because of the rice paddies they drop into, and those rice paddies are real wet
and they had to get away of letting these bombs drop.
So it was just a money-making thing, I think, too.
There was other people involved.

Many critics of the Vietnam War say that we had become so obsessed with fighting communism that we violated the very principles of our own democratic government, the principles that the American forefathers had thought the country was going to stand on.
For example, Nixon and Johnson had lied to the American people a lot of times.
and the CIA was misused for the surveillance of the domestic problems and that was not the intention of the CIA when they made that agency.
So do you think all these actions of the American government can be justified?
I guess by being in the business that Nixon and Johnson are both in and they're the highest office, they used
their facilities like the CIA to accomplish missions that probably in no other unit you could probably accomplish.
We had even your other forces would have your espionage out there doing the same thing we did.
So if we got other countries out there doing the same thing, even though by political law or war, it was just mostly that through
the government that they actually said they violated the misuse of those units just because of that.

If it had been an actual combat situation where it would have been really like it was in World War II in Korea or something, they would probably, nobody would have probably said anything about using that unit as what they were doing, I think.
But because it was not, Vietnam was never considered as a war, it was more of a policing action, more like

Korea except we did a little different in Korea that I think that what they did would probably not have been even nothing would have been said about but since it was not an actual type situation it just became political and these were type of things that they did just so that they probably people bring out like they're doing anything when you're up for elections you get out the dirty you get out your dirty weapons and those were things that they they bring up saying that to bring against these people

If the Vietnamese culture were to be similar to the American culture, and if the Vietnamese people looked like the American people, do you think it would have been much more easier for America to accomplish goals in Vietnam?
In other words, do you think there was a cultural conflict in Vietnam?
I don't think there was a cultural conflict.
I just think that the government there asked our government to assist them
in a situation of not being, coming under communism, and the Viet Cong were being supported by Red China and different things like this, even by Russia.
Weapons and stuff were being sent to Vietnam through the Hanoi and different things like this.
The only culture thing was, as you work with these people, especially if you, working like I was in Special Forces, and you went out with the units
like the Mike Force or a Ranger outfit, that if you went out there with these people, you did not know whether you were taking good people or were you taking a nipple trader.
And otherwise, I think the culture or the people got along with the Americans, in fact,
They thought real highly of the Americans until we started pulling out.
And then they felt real bad that we pulled out and left them.
Did you talk to any of your... Did you have any Vietnamese friends?
Yes.
Did you talk to any of them while America was pulling out of Vietnam?
I was not there when they were pulling out because I left in 71 and they did not pull out until 73.
But I've...
ate with them and things like this when I was in Spaceship Forces and different things like this.
And they're just like me or you.
Even if the guy was a double agent, if he had no intentions of killing you and was just there for mostly intelligent purposes, he could be just as good a friend as anybody as long as you didn't know.
So you could work alongside with anybody.
What do you think about the South Vietnamese government?
A lot of people have criticized the United States for supporting a very despotic government that was really, you know, ruled the Vietnamese people with the iron hand.
they had corruption in their government, but the United States was supporting them, people say, because they just wanted to fight the greater evil of communism.
Do you believe that the South Vietnamese government was really corrupt?
On that, I can go along with that.
I think the Vietnamese government was corrupt.
They, because...
They would take anything the Americans were giving away.
Gave them, like I said, we supported them in monies and different things like this.
We supported them in equipment and things like this, ammunition, guns.
And we supported them.
And you had a lot of people in their political government that abused what, especially your higher ranking officers in the government or anything like that, in the military.
Yes, and they abused their people.

I've seen this, but like you say, we were only there for the purpose of them asking us to support them in a cause that we felt that would benefit the United States in the longer run that Vietnam not become communism.
But after a period of time,

people and the judgment of the people decided that we were it was a losing call since we've been here close to 10 years or more and nothing was going on like you said we've been dropping bombs and had dropped more bombs and uh on uh in Vietnam than we dropped in World War II and it was a losing call so why keep doing this and not be going gaining any footage

And then when the United States moved out, a lot of their people and their higher-up government in different places like this are now living in the United States because they can no longer stay within Vietnam because once the country was taken over, either the people would do them in or the Viet Cong or the Vietnamese or Red China or whoever came in would actually physically put them in prison and re-interrogate them to become a communism.
which is what they do now.
They're trying to rehabilitate their captured soldiers over there.
They're in school and they sit around and have to go attend a class, mostly of it is in communism, stating what the Vietnamese government wants them to do.
Did you encounter anybody who was associated with the Viet Cong?
Did you talk to anybody who was...

There was one time when we were working and when I was in Special Forces and I was there in a camp and we were building, like I said, we were building Special Forces camps and we hire civilians or people to come in and work alongside us and help us build.
This also was supporting their economy to help the people out in those areas.
We were paying...
the out people, they were not military, but they were civilian people, Vietnamese people, to come in and work alongside us to build these special forces camps.
And there was one time when we were there that word was out that one of the guys that was there was a double agent.
He was there, he was wearing white pajamas, but when he was there during the day,

The reason why we noticed that he was more on the other side was we started noticing, because we have people watching our people when we're out there, and I guess he must not know somebody's watching him, and he was pacing off from bunker to bunker, and the time he left there, because we let him go until the end of the day.
At the end of the day, we kept him and found out that he was...
under interrogation and asking him that he was a hardcore Viet Cong agent that was sent in to infiltrate and find out our dimensions of the thing.
So if he'd left there that night, most likely that night, we'd have probably been mortared severely.
And he would have had real bad casualties because he would have been able to tell him exactly where
to shift their guns and stuff or their mortars when they come in exactly right on our bunkers and things like this.
So what did you all do with that guy?
Well, he just became a prisoner after that.
Then we interrogated him, and then after that, by a policy of the American government, we called in a chopper because we were sitting out in the middle of nowhere.
We called in a chopper and sent him back for higher-up interrogation, and that's where, actually, physically, they more did the interrogation.
